rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 10–28
rsbNotes.text:
10:1–28:27 The Divided Kingdom. In this section the writer makes use of 1 Kin. 12–2 Kin. 17. His record of the period of the divided monarchy does not rehearse the harsh condemnation of the northern tribes found in Kings, focusing instead on events in Judah where the temple was and the Davidic king lived. Throughout this section, the writer reports how the conditions in the kingdom depended on the nation’s faithfulness to God. As readers considered these events, they could see clearly the choices for blessing and curse in their own day.

In telling about Rehoboam’s kingship, the writer makes broad use of Kings (cf. 10:1–11:4 with 1 Kin. 12:1–24; 12:9–16 with 1 Kin. 14:21, 25–31), while presenting the material in accord with his own theological understanding and emphasis. The account is presented in two parts (chs. 10; 11 and 12:1–14), each part narrating a problematic situation, prophetic encounter, and divine blessing. The conclusion is a notice of his wars with Jeroboam and his death (12:15, 16). The chapters impress on the readers God’s curse against pride and infidelity and the benefits of living in humility and obedience to the prophetic word (20:20 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 17:1–21:3
rsbNotes.text: 17:1–21:3 The account of Jehoshaphat’s reign incorporates most of the record in Kings (cf. 1 Kin. 22:1–35 with 2 Chr. 18:2–34; 1 Kin. 22:41–46, 49 with 2 Chr. 20:31–36), adding some material and a summary of his reign.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 17:1
rsbNotes.text: 17:1 Jehoshaphat. He reigned 872–848 b.c. Jehoshaphat was probably co-regent with Asa for three years (872–869 b.c.) because of Asa’s illness (16:11–14; cf. 20:31 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 17:2
rsbNotes.text: 17:2 cities of Ephraim. See note 14:6.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 17:6
rsbNotes.text: 17:6 high places. See note 14:3.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 17:7
rsbNotes.text: 17:7 In the third year. This teaching mission probably took place just after Asa’s death (17:1 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 17:7–8
rsbNotes.text: 17:7, 8 officials . . . Levites. The royal officials were accompanied by Levites whom Moses had ordained to be teachers of the people (1 Chr. 26:29–32 note; 2 Chr. 19:5–11 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 17:9
rsbNotes.text: 17:9 the Book of the Law of the Lord. The identity of this book is uncertain. It may have included the entire Pentateuch, but in light of the nature of Jehoshaphat’s reforms (19:4–11), it may have been limited to the Book of Deuteronomy.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 17:10
rsbNotes.text: 17:10 fear of the Lord. Fear of the divine power displayed in Jehoshaphat’s military strength gave him peace with other nations (1 Chr. 14:17 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 17:12
rsbNotes.text: 17:12 fortresses and store cities. See note 1 Chr. 11:5.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 17:14–18
rsbNotes.text: 17:14–18 For these large numbers see note 1 Chr. 12:23.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 18:1–19:3
rsbNotes.text: 18:1–19:3 In contrast with his early years, Jehoshaphat came under God’s curse because he ignored the prophetic warning and made an alliance with the northern kingdom (16:2 note; 20:20 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 18:1
rsbNotes.text: 18:1 he made a marriage alliance. The author refers to the marriage of Jehoshaphat’s son, Jehoram, to Athaliah, daughter of Ahab (21:6; 22:2). In Kings, Ahab represents the depths of apostasy in the northern kingdom (1 Kin. 16:30). Cf. 19:1–3 and see note 16:2.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 18:2
rsbNotes.text:
18:2 induced. The Hebrew expression can have the connotation of enticing to apostasy (Deut. 13:6; 1 Chr. 21:1).

Ramoth-gilead. A city thirty miles east of the Jordan River, closer to the Sea of Galilee than the Dead Sea. It had belonged to Israel since the time of Moses (Deut. 4:43; Josh. 20:8). Ben-hadad failed to return the city to Israel as he had agreed (1 Kin. 20:34).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 18:18
rsbNotes.text: 18:18 I saw the Lord. Micaiah’s vision of heavenly deliberations (cf. Job 1:6–12; Is. 6:1–8; Zech. 3) demonstrates that the sovereignty of God extends over evil events (1 Chr. 21:1 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 18:28
rsbNotes.text: 18:28 In contrast with Rehoboam (11:4) and Asa after his first battle (15:1–8), Jehoshaphat paid no attention to the prophet’s warning. As a result, Jehoshaphat barely escaped with his life (18:31). See note 20:20.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 18:31
rsbNotes.text: 18:31 Jehoshaphat cried out. The writer adds to the words of 1 Kings 22:32 the explicit statement that “the Lord helped him,” recalling the request of Solomon’s dedicatory prayer (6:34 note; 7:14 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 18:34
rsbNotes.text: 18:34 he died. The writer does not repeat the details of Ahab’s death found in 1 Kin. 22:36–40.
